metadata.case_name: Messrs. Pratapray Manmohandas v. Bombay Bullion Association Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant trading as Messrs. Pratapray Manmohandas, bullion merchant in Bombay, member of Bombay Bullion Association Ltd. (defendant No. 1, respondent No. 1).
Respondents 2 to 7 (defendants 2 to 7) were members of Clearing House Committee under bye-laws of 1st respondent.
Appellant entered forward transactions with defendants 8 to 12 from May 30, 1949 to June 30, 1949.
Hawala rate of transactions fixed on June 13, 1949.
On June 14, 1949, appellant admitted clearance sheet under bye-law 131 including transactions with defendants 8 to 12; transactions tallied.
Appellant disputed transactions with defendants 8 to 12 as fictitious and illegal; did not include amounts in balance sheet submitted.
On June 21, 1949 (Valan day settlement day), appellant claimed reference to arbitration under bye-law 38 regarding disputed items.
On June 21, 1949, defendants 8 to 12 complained to respondent Association that appellant had not issued kaplis vouchers.
At 3 p.m. on June 21, 1949, appellant received notice from Clearing House Committee (respondents 2 to 7) to appear.
Appellant appeared before Clearing House Committee with solicitor and counsel; contended Committee had no jurisdiction due to arbitration claim.
Clearing House Committee heard explanation and passed resolution under bye-law 155(4) declaring appellant a defaulter.
Appellant filed suit on June 20, 1952 for declaration that resolution dated June 21, 1949 was bad in law, inoperative, ultra vires, not binding; for damages and reinstatement as member.
Respondents pleaded transactions not fictitious; appellant refused kaplis at meeting, defaulted under bye-law 155(4).
Suit tried by Tendolkar J.; appellant led no evidence; respondents examined Mr. Trikamdas Dwarkadas (solicitor present at June 21, 1949 meeting). Suit dismissed June 6, 1956.
Appeal to Bombay High Court (Appeal No. 71 of 1956) dismissed July 12, 1957.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave.
Trial court found appellant and counsel voluntarily left meeting after indicating unwillingness to submit kaplis; no genuine dispute for arbitration; no intention to give kaplis.
High Court held bye-law 155(4) requires opportunity to submit kaplis after explanation (locus poenitentiae), but appellant had no intention.

legal_issues.text: Interpretation of bye-law 155(4): Whether Clearing House Committee must give time after demanding explanation to submit kapli before declaring defaulter.
Whether appellant was given opportunity to submit kaplis after hearing, or if decision made in his absence; whether he voluntarily left meeting after indicating no intention to pay.

petitioner_arguments.text: Resolution declaring defaulter bad in law, inoperative, ultra vires, not binding; no jurisdiction due to arbitration claim under bye-law 38; heard then asked to leave, decision in absence; no opportunity to submit kaplis after explanation under bye-law 155(4).
Transactions with defendants 8-12 fictitious and illegal.

respondent_arguments.text: Transactions genuine, not fictitious; appellant refused to give kaplis at meeting, defaulted; entitled to declare defaulter under bye-law 155(4); appellant voluntarily left after challenging jurisdiction and indicating no payment.
Appellant deliberately made false allegation of being asked to leave to bolster plea.

court_reasoning.text: Both lower courts found appellant voluntarily left meeting after indicating unwillingness to submit kaplis; finding justified by evidence including Mr. Trikamdas Dwarkadas' attendance book and minutes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant had no intention of paying; wanted arbitration first.

court_reasoning.text: Bye-law 155(4) requires calling defaulter, demanding explanation, and thereafter if kapli not submitted, declare defaulter; does not mandate specific time (e.g., notice by phone/letter) post-explanation if clear no payment intended; time depends on circumstances, futile where no intention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interpretation accords with language: explanation first, then opportunity, but no fixed period required given settlement deadlines.

court_reasoning.text: Transactions entered in clearance sheet, tallied, shown in olia; contentions false to gain time; Committee acted with due consideration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Settlement by 3:30 p.m. June 21, 1949; appellant clear no payment till arbitration.

holdings.text: Appellant voluntarily left after clear refusal to pay; no genuine arbitration dispute to evade liability; bye-law 155(4) satisfied as opportunity futile.
Bye-law 155(4) does not require specific time post-explanation if no intention to comply; procedure reasonable given prompt settlement needs.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, confirming High Court and trial court decrees dismissing suit; held Clearing House Committee justified in declaring appellant defaulter under bye-law 155(4) as he had no intention to submit kaplis despite opportunity.

key_quotes.text: "If any member does not submit a kapli in the prescribed form in respect of the amount found claimable from him to his party creditor, the Clearing House Committee shall call him and demand an explanation from him and can thereafter, if such a kapli is not submitted the Clearing House Committee can declare him a defaulter."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Full text of bye-law 155(4) central to interpretation

key_quotes.text: "where it is made absolutely clear that no payment is going to be made the giving of time is wholly without utility."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.key_observation: Core holding on why no further time required
